cards.back: The rate of flow of electric charge through a conductor.
Ampere (A), 1 A = 1 C/s.
Electric potential difference between two points.
Volt (V), 1 V = 1 J/C.
V = I * R, where V is voltage, I is current, and R is resistance.
Ohm (Ω).
Material, length, cross-sectional area, temperature.
A component that opposes the flow of current.
R_total = R₁ + R₂ + ... + Rn.
1 / R_total = 1 / R₁ + 1 / R₂ + ... + 1 / Rn.
Current is the same through all components.
Voltage divides across resistors: V_total = V₁ + V₂ + ... + Vn.
Voltage is the same across all branches.
Current divides among branches: I_total = I₁ + I₂ + ... + In.

cards.front: What is power in a circuit?
cards.back: Rate of energy transfer: P = V * I.
P = I² * R or P = V² / R.
A component that stores electrical energy in an electric field.
Farad (F), 1 F = 1 C/V.
1 / C_total = 1 / C₁ + 1 / C₂ + ... + 1 / Cn.
C_total = C₁ + C₂ + ... + Cn.
A circuit where current flows in one direction only.
A circuit where current periodically reverses direction.
The sum of currents entering a junction equals the sum leaving it.
The sum of voltage drops around any closed loop equals the sum of voltage sources.

cards.front: Series combination of resistors – voltage division?
cards.back: Vₙ = (Rₙ / R_total) * V_total.

cards.front: Parallel combination of resistors – current division?
cards.back: Iₙ = (R_total / Rₙ) * I_total.
A device used to measure current; connected in series.
A device used to measure voltage; connected in parallel.
A low-resistance path that bypasses the intended circuit, potentially causing high current.
A break in the circuit that stops current flow.
Resistance within a battery or power source that reduces terminal voltage.

cards.front: Formula for total voltage with internal resistance?
cards.back: V_terminal = V_source - I * r_internal.
Any device that consumes electrical energy.
A safety device that melts when current exceeds a limit.
A resettable switch that opens the circuit when current is too high.
A material property: ρ = R * A / L.
Ohm·meter (Ω·m).
Resistance of metals increases with temperature; for semiconductors, it decreases.
